answers.answer: I never had that, but being a nurse, I'm sure you know that is considered excessive edema. Granted the 12 hour shift had a great deal to do with it, but I would definitely let your doctor know in the morning. How is your blood pressure? I guess you also know all the signs of preeclampsia. Hey, why don't you take a picture of your legs and show it to your doc! Lol.....pictures don't lie.

I know being a nurse it is excessive, I also know that when it comes to maternity I am clueless, lol, not my forte in nursing, I know in the third trimester you have a bigger blood supply and all the stuff that goes with increased heat. been 90 plus degrees in good ol upstate ny. that coupled with being on my feet for 12 hours doesnt help, guess I was worried about the heart not functioning properly etc.. I hate to be one of those patients that call the doctor over every little thing .although I will say, I am an excellent nurse BUT... one H ell of an awful patient, thanks for your reply,
Good luck, it doesn't sound like you will be working much longer.

If you're on your feet a lot, your feet and ankles will swell.  When you stay off them, it should be better.   If you develop swelling in your hands and face too, that's much more concerning.I know its practically impossible, but you really need to find time every couple of hours to elevate your legs if its this bad.  Or your doctor may need to put you out on disability.  Has your doctor seen them when they're really bad?  Are you using knee high Teds?  If so, you may have to switch to thigh highs (oh so attractive!) or compression maternity panty hose, if you can find such a thing.
Or cut your hours down to 8 hr or 6 hour shifts.
